title: Monday, 10th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:01am

Trust you had a nice weekend

PM11:01am

Fab weather

11:01 am
PM11:01am

But obv good to be back inside, staring at screens

PM11:02am

Tell you who won't have had a good weekend

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Richard Howson

PM11:02am

Now ex Carillion

PM11:02am

I thought about running the pic upside down

11:02 am
PM11:02am

As we sometimes do for hapless ceos

PM11:02am

But on this occasion thought it a bit mean

PM11:03am

And I'm trying to be less mean

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Bryce will probably remain mean, regularly. But I'm minded to be less so

PM11:03am

Should we go straight into Carillion Bryce?

PM11:03am

Rest of the market is pretty mixed

11:03 am
PM11:04am

Footsie's ahead 24 points

BE11:04am

I guess so, sure.

PM11:04am

All of europe pretty positive

11:04 am
PM11:04am

But Carillion the one of the only solid pieces of corporate news

PM11:05am

Painful trading statement here https://www.invest...1707100700105229K/

BE11:05am

So, fun chart.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

PM11:05am

What's that short interest?

BE11:05am

Yep. Carillion share price (white) vs Carillion short interest as percent of free float (green).

11:05 am
BE11:06am

It's one of these where everyone saw it coming.

BE11:06am

Apart from Blackrock!

BE11:06am

Which has been a holder since about 2011, or perhaps even before, and has been adding throughout this year.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Dozy thing to do

BE11:07am

I mean, everyone has raised concerns about Carillion. Everyone.

BE11:07am

There was even a highly flaky bid rumour around a month or so ago that flagged that longs wanted out.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Take the signal! Jees.

BE11:08am

But let's head back into the detail of what was said.

BE11:08am

Trading conditions deteriorated dramatically.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

KPMG contract review results in an £845m provision.

PM11:09am

Ouch

BE11:09am

That's four years of operating profit, to put it in context.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Debt's now going in the wrong direction.

BE11:10am

Divi suspended.

BE11:10am

FY revenue guidance foes down to £4.8-5.0bn

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Board announce a fire sale to try and get debt back into line.

BE11:11am

Going to try to raise £125m from exiting most of the Middle East Construction business. (/And good luck with that!)

PM11:11am

This feels like it's headed for an emergency rights issue, arleady.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Won't be able to cut / sell quickly enough

BE11:11am

I would see that as a significant risk, among others.

BE11:11am

UBS incoming.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

We have long argued that Carillion is running excessive risk with total net debt incl pension of £1.4bn before considering around £0.5bn reverse factoring. While dividend cut and asset sales are the first step, we struggle to see how they will be sufficient in reducing net debt. We therefore believe the immediate reaction to the share price will likely be dramatic, possibly down more than 50%, though we recognise the volatility will be high and with c30% shares on loan some short closing may support.

BE11:12am

And RBC ......

BE11:12am

Key near-term focus has to be on stabilizing the balance sheet, given debt levels and the scale of the pension deficit. The share price will react accordingly
today, and we are unlikely to get any concrete resolution on the financial position of the business until the interims in September. In our view, the group would
need to raise a significant amount (£500m+) to restore stability and in the near term, we would expect others to be running the slide rule over the business.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

"£500m+"

PM11:13am

Right

PM11:13am

So this really is a candidate for the London Approach

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Hey, ive found that "bid story" -- from June 23

PM11:14am

Shall I share?

PM11:14am

From that website we never name

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Sure, why not.

PM11:14am

Carillion (CLLN), the British support services business is rumoured to be aware parties are running the rule over them. The contenders could be those such as international private equity companies Middle East infrastructure funds sovereign wealth funds. The company is said to have taken on advisers, concerned it could be caught out by speculative vultures. Even their bankers suggesting they are vulnerable!

In the City of London, some are even saying Carillion has already had a knock on the door / a takeover approach. As the share price is so low and gives the impression of being falling knife, a bid around 275p could be delivered, and perhaps would be more than enough as an offer level.

PM11:14am

Oops

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Ah well, win some lose some.

PM11:15am

(Oh, sorry, I said early i was trying not to be mean...)

BE11:15am

Oh, and here's Liberum.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

This morning we reduced FD EPS by 27% to 25.6p. The £845m provision is huge however we look at it. No clearer what exactly has gone wrong. Carillion will get into trouble way before it breaches its covenants. No quick fixes for the balance sheet. Hard to see a solution without equity. We identify the three major head-winds for cash. Management keen to highlight the attractions of the business. Unrated and the balance sheet will continue to overshadow the business.

BE11:16am

Here are the cash headwinds.

BE11:16am

1) Greater selectivity in UK Construction will reduce risk, but it will also reduce negative working capital (up to 10% of contract value is typically pre-paid). 2) Restructuring will cost money. Management indicated that it would not cost much. We question that. 3) Management indicates that there is £412m of reverse factoring at H1 (lower than the £498m at the FY), but also suggest that this is unlikely to be part of the long term funding of the business. This needs to be reduced further. We also question whether the banks will be willing to continue with this facility given the reduced covenant of Carillion.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

As you might expect from a management that may be about to seek cash from the market, they were keen to highlight the attractions of the business and reluctant to provide granular guidance (e.g. on the Support Service margin). The key operational risk is that the large SS business results in reduced customer confidence due to the weaker balance sheet. It is positive that there are no large SS renewals until the end of 2019, and c. 90% of revenues are for the public and regulated sectors.

BE11:17am

The shares are trading on a revised CY 2018 P/E of 4.4x. However, we believe that the balance sheet will continue to overshadow the business. Despite the c.30% share price fall today, we believe that it will be hard to attract fresh money ahead of what could be a huge equity raise.

BE11:17am

Anyway.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Sector getting hit too ......

Balfour Beatty PLC (BBY:LSE): Last: 259.68, down 6.52 (-2.45%), High: 265.30, Low: 252.70, Volume: 1.23m
PM11:17am

Not surprised

11:18 am
Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 271.70, up 1.7 (+0.63%), High: 272.00, Low: 268.20, Volume: 398.74k
BE11:18am

Oh, Mitie's up! Ignore that one.

BE11:19am

The rest of them are .... well, they're dead already, mostly. This sector's been a basket case for as long as we've been doing this.

11:19 am
undefined
BE11:20am

Sticking with M&A rumours of sorts, the Aveva rumour reached the Sunday Times.

AVEVA Group PLC (AVV:LSE): Last: 2,069, up 51 (+2.53%), High: 2,108, Low: 2,030, Volume: 447.41k
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Schneider mulling things.

BE11:20am

Things are being mulled by Schneider.

BE11:21am

Actually, wee bit surprised that the shares are up on this, because it all feels even more premature than the rumours we've reported a couple of times already.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Such as here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-07-07/

BE11:21am

And here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-07-06/

BE11:21am

And here: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-06-23/

11:21 am
BE11:21am

And here: https://www.ft.com...-9fed-c19e2700005f

BE11:22am

You get the idea.

PM11:22am

hehehe

11:22 am
PM11:22am

It's tough working on a Sunday paper...

BE11:22am

It is. I doff my cap to their indefatigably.

BE11:23am

Though I'm also aware they mostly don't read us on Monday.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Here's Caz on the latest retread.

BE11:23am

We liked the strategic rationale behind the first deal, and while certain logistics were clearly problematic, we have always thought M&A was still possible. The continued weakness in end markets (and revs down 4% in FY17), combined with the long-standing CEO moving into a more advisory role last year, plus shareholders becoming more proactive at the recent AGM all point to the potential for Aveva to be more amenable to a deal with Schneider Software, in our opinion.

undefined
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Want something slightly less familiar?

PM11:24am

Sure

BE11:25am

So .............. Mentioned in passing in the Saturday paper about gossip of possible consolidation in the motor insurance sector.

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Ok...

BE11:25am

And there is a specific rumour out there.

BE11:25am

The idea here is that eSure has been weighing up whether to remain independent.

11:25 am
PM11:26am

Blimey

esure Group PLC (ESUR:LSE): Last: 297.20, down 4 (-1.33%), High: 305.80, Low: 294.50, Volume: 185.42k
BE11:26am

And has one of its house brokers investigating options at the moment.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

(House brokers are JP Morgan and Deutsche Bank, according to my records.)

BE11:26am

So, this one needs a bit of context.

BE11:26am

Turn back to the eSure's IPO in 2013.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Where it was sold as a growth stock, 14 or 15 times earnings, and set to rake in market share.

BE11:26am

Then warned pretty much immediately because the pricing cycle turned negative.

PM11:27am

(You've turned the price positive Bryce)

11:27 am
BE11:27am

(Caveat emptor, folks. Read everything first.)

BE11:27am

The motor insurance pricing cycle is now extremely positive .

BE11:27am

Confused.com/Willis Towers Watson Index showed second quarter UK motor rates up 18% yoy, 8.5% qoq.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Motor is nearly three quarters of eSure's revenue and basically all its earnings. There's 10% or so from home crossselling but the line is lossmaking. It's nearly a pure play.

BE11:28am

You'll also remember in November eSure spun off GoCompare for £300m, yet it's already clawed back all that value.

BE11:28am

Meaning it's now crossed over the flotation PE and gone through it like a rocket.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Okay --- there are a number of reasons for that. One is that eSure specialises in older drivers so has been less exposed to the Ogden review, as older drivers damage themselves less.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:29am

However, those three reasons don't fully explain the chart. And it's quite a chart. Let me get the chart.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

PM11:29am

Yeah, the progress through Q! and Q2 this year is extraordinary

BE11:29am

That kind of surge in valuation is likely to be greatly of interest to Sir Peter Wood, Chairman and 30.8% shareholder.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Who at the age of 71 would be forgiven for looking to crystalise some of his investments.

BE11:30am

And who -- given he bought 70% of eSure from Lloyds in 2010 for about £185m -- would probably consider the current valuation reasonable.

PM11:30am

I think he would

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Potential buyers are trickier to identify at this kind of price, however.

BE11:30am

Here's what the market share looks like.

BE11:30am

11:30 am
PM11:31am

Sector is so fragmented

BE11:31am

Yup. And Sir Peter founded Direct Line, of course, which would make it a tidy home for eSure, so it would be unsurprising if it were sounded out during any kind of sale process.

BE11:31am

Though DL's much much cheaper in PE terms so not sure how that'd work.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Then there's Hastings, which on approximately the same PE as eSure. Though it'd be a huge deal for them.

BE11:32am

Second on the list to Sir Peter, incidentally, is ToscaFund with 17% of eSure. I don't think it's a stretch to suggest there could be some motivated sellers in here.

PM11:33am

No stretch at all

11:33 am
BE11:33am

We are, however, flagging it up as a possibility and a rumour. It's not the kind of thing that would require a statement, I'd have thought.

BE11:33am

Worth keeping an eye on though.

undefined
11:33 am
PM11:33am

Nice one

PM11:34am

305p live -- eSure

BE11:34am

And very nearly a record high. Don't get carried away.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Anyway, onto other matters.

PM11:34am

307p

PM11:34am

Rabble missed this all -- they are busy discussing tax

11:34 am
PM11:35am

Not quite sure why -- when you are dangling quality RAW

BE11:36am

Fine. We can bring them out of whatever cul-de-sac of tedium they've backed into with some blistering sellside.

BE11:36am

Schroders! That's up.

11:36 am
Schroders PLC (SDR:LSE): Last: 3,205, up 48 (+1.52%), High: 3,241, Low: 3,201, Volume: 190.10k
BE11:37am

Peter Lenardos at RBC turns positive.

BE11:37am

Mostly in a results preview ahead of half-years on 27 July.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

The underlying business is in good shape and cost control will likely surprise on the upside. Given Schroders' relative share price underperformance recently and a conservative consensus, we believe current levels represent an attractive entry point and we upgrade to Outperform from Sector Perform.

BE11:37am

.......... So ............

BE11:38am

[At results] we believe the focus will be on the net flows figure, which is likely to underwhelm given the significant one-off redemption booked last quarter. However, in our opinion, the focus should instead be on profitability, and we expect that the interim results will show strong year-on-year growth as the underlying business remains resilient and cost control surprises on the upside. Indeed, in our opinion, consensus is currently a conservative representation of the company’s future potential.

Further, we note Schroders’ relative underperformance, with its share price up only 5% year-to-date against the sector at +17%. Combined with a considerable short position in the company of ~10%, we believe current levels represent an attractive entry level to a quality, diversified and global company, with a best-in-class balance sheet (and M&A optionality) as well as a credible and accomplished management team. Our increased price target of 3400p (on higher forecasts) implies an all-in return of 11% in a fully valued market (in our view), which we believe warrants an Outperform rating.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

RBC's also keen on Man Group, though not as keen as it was.

Man Group PLC (EMG:LSE): Last: 153.60, up 0.7 (+0.46%), High: 155.50, Low: 153.40, Volume: 1.08m
BE11:39am

While we’re still positive on the stock, we’re less enthusiastic, as the declining revenue margin and regulatory capital requirement review cloud a potential investment, and share price outperformance begins to cap further upside. Nevertheless, further upside does still exist given Man’s material earnings growth (on strong flows and cost control), high capital returns and discounted valuation. On a 16% implied all-in return, we reiterate our Outperform rating.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Which reminds me -- when I try and look at an AHL NAV quote on the office Bloomberg machine, it doesn't met me.

BE11:40am

I get something about not being accredited to see it.

PM11:41am

hmm

11:41 am
BE11:41am

It used to be that Man published the NAV for AHL every week via RNS. Then it stopped and put it on its website.

BE11:41am

Then it created a balkanisation of AHL quotes that had the (I'm sure unintended!) consequence of resetting all the high water marks.

BE11:41am

And now, I can't even see those?

11:41 am
BE11:42am

It's all most unsatisfactory.

PM11:42am

Indeed

BE11:42am

Have a bit more RBC.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Because of the amount of Man’s performance fees – and the variance of these fees – we continue to value Man’s performance fees separately from its management fees, which are relatively stable and dependent on FUM levels.
Our valuation methodology is unchanged – we continue to use the one-plus-a-half valuation methodology to value Man; whereby we take a multiple to value the management fees, and then we take half of that multiple to value the performance fees. We value 2018E management fee EPS at 13x and 2018E management fee EBITDA at 9x, in line with the longer-term sector averages. Using the one-plus-a-half valuation methodology, we therefore value 2018E performance fee EPS at 6.5x and 2018E performance fee EBITDA at 4.5x.
Our valuation accounts for Man’s surplus capital position, which we forecast to be $350 million at year-end 2017, pro-forma the $100 million share buyback programme. We utilise our 2017 forecast of 1,668 million weighted average fully diluted shares and maintain the exchange rate between the British pound and the US dollar at 1.25.
Using the above methodology, we derive a rounded price target of 170p, which we believe justifies an Outperform rating.

undefined
PM11:43am

TalkTalk is losing its FD

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Iain Torrens

PM11:43am

Internal replacement -- Kate Ferry

PM11:44am

Charles Dunstone making changes?

11:44 am
PM11:44am

I suspect so

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 183.40, down 1.6 (-0.86%), High: 189.70, Low: 183.00, Volume: 451.48k
undefined
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Market Tech mentioned on the right.

BE11:46am

On the back of the third major fire at Stables Market in less than ten years.

BE11:47am

There's a statement from Market Tech, which is in the process of an MBO of course.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

https://www.invest...1707101125235939K/

BE11:47am

An isolated fire broke out in a building adjacent to the market hall area of Camden Lock Market overnight which was brought quickly under control by the Emergency Services and we are now working closely with them to investigate the cause. Thankfully no one was injured during the incident. While a small section of Camden Lock market will be closed off to the public until further notice as a precaution, the rest of Camden Lock market and the wider area, including Stables Market and Union Street, will be fully open and operating and welcoming visitors and customers as usual today.

BE11:48am

For those who don't know Camden Market, the market hall area is the covered bit with the brass horses.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

The proper junk-y bit. Grubby 1970s toys, books, broken sunglasses. Not just witless tee-shirts and bongs shaped like skulls.

BE11:49am

Notable that Market Tech's share price has gone ......... up?

Market Tech Holdings Ltd (MKT:LSE): Last: 187.75, up 0.5 (+0.27%), High: 187.75, Low: 187.75, Volume: 2
11:50 am
BE11:50am

The past two Camden Market fires resulted in redevelopment of the areas affected, which locals grumbled about as stealth gentrification.

BE11:50am

One can speculate about whether the same thing might happen again. But one probably shouldn't.

BE11:51am

(@alewis2005: that's him.)

11:50 am
undefined
BE11:51am

Otherwise, fantasy M&A?

PM11:51am

You are all surprises today Bryce

11:51 am
Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 4,251, up 72.5 (+1.74%), High: 4,262, Low: 4,183, Volume: 1.04m
PM11:51am

Lightbulb

BE11:52am

Pablo Zuanic at SIG reckons Kraft might go hostile.

11:51 am
PM11:52am

Really?

BE11:52am

Yep. I'm calling it SIG because I can't spell Susquehanna.

BE11:52am

Zuanic was required reading through SAB-AB Inbev, you might remember.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Here's his current thinking.

BE11:53am

... we are now coming around to the view that a hostile bid for ULVR is more than 75% likely.

PM11:53am

That's quite a call

11:53 am
PM11:53am

What's it based on?

BE11:53am

Summary: By mid-August the six-month hiatus required by British take-over law will have passed, and KHC could proceed to make a hostile bid for Unilever. The impediment to KHC going back for Unilever (nevermind that the original $143Bn price tag could now be ~$200Bn) is neither ULVR CEO Paul Polman, nor British PM Theresa May, nor anti-trust agencies. It is Warren Buffett. He, who famously said he prefers to go where he is welcome. With a $30Bn investment in KHC (worth a lot less without further M&A), we think he will come around (3G has had half a year to make its case). We think it is telling KHC has done nothing (M&A wise) for the past five months; we think the rebuff/defeat is not something 3G/KHC can tolerate if they plan to continue to roll-up the CPG space (BUD never went away in making its various bids over the years); ULVR remains a “good fit” as with it KHC expands in food and builds an HPC platform (we certainly think it is a better fit than a pure HPC play; market chatter of a KHC bid for Colgate was probably just a shrewd decoy). A 20% premium to the current ULVR share price would imply ~50% gains year-to-date for ULVR shareholders (i.e., we think they would fold). As we show here, a $200Bn deal, 25-35% equity funded, could be accretive in the mid-20%s for KHC shareholders assuming new KHC shares are placed at a discount (accretion could be much higher without a discount). A mix of $10-$12Bn equity investments each by 3G and Berkshire, a preferred stock placement Omaha-funded ($10Bn), plus asset divestitures of $25-$35Bn (from KHC: Oscar Mayer to JBS, coffee to Coty, frozen foods to CAG/PF/LW, baby food; from ULVR ice cream and cosmetics) could all bring net debt to EBITDA below 5x post deal. Our Dec’17 PT is now $91 as we only take a 5% peer premium (vs. 10% before) given slower synergy realization; we still add a 20% “surcharge” for likely M&A accretion. See our price target math in the appendix (KHC is down 9% in the last 3 months vs. 0% for S5CONS; YTD it is down -5% vs. +6%).

PM11:55am

hmm

11:55 am
BE11:55am

So, there's some dollar maths in there that I'll not go into. The upshot is that Unilever is now $200bn, and that Kraft could still 20% on that, and still make it work.

PM11:55am

This assumes Buffett makes a full u-turn

PM11:56am

When has he led a hostile bid -- never mind a hostile on of this size??

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Fair question.

BE11:57am

The model also assumes $35bn in disposals post purchase. Unilever's cosmetics, ice cream, Kraft's coffee, frozen foods, Oscar Mayer and baby food.

PM11:57am

And Polman's not suddenly going to say " fine -- take the company"

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Not even at a 20% premium, no.

PM11:57am

I know Zuanic has form, but all the political / anti-trust obstacles that stopped this in its tracks last time are still pretty much there

PM11:58am

More likely, I'd say, is Buffett finding a way to get out of Kraft.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

And his Brazilian partnership -- which can't feel comfortable in Trump's America

BE11:59am

I'd not disagree with any of this. However, it's nice to have something sparky to share of a Monday.

PM11:59am

Indeed

11:59 am
undefined
BE12:00pm

Cripes!

BE12:00pm

Bernstein Said to Quote $150,000 for Basic Research Under MiFID

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Citi's also put up the fund manager paywall in recent days, I'm told.

BE12:01pm

Which isn't good news for anyone really.

PM12:01pm

The Bernstein price tag doesn't surprise me, actually. Have you seen the size of their 6th Ave offices?

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

I've seen the quality of the research, which I appreciate every time it lands in my inbox.

PM12:01pm

(Boncoeur -- we don't know how this will all play out)

BE12:02pm

I'd pay $150,000, had I $150,000, which I don't.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

(I mean, I'd probably buy some other things first, like food and etc. But I'd not be adverse to paying $150,000.)

BE12:03pm

Anyway, are we done? It's through midday.

PM12:03pm

I think so

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:03pm

eSure drift backed to 302p, btw

PM12:03pm

But keep an eye on that

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

Back tomorrow

PM12:04pm

Bye

BE11:29am

The second reason is that the growth plan put forward by management is more gradual this time. And the third reason is of course the pricing cycle.
